articles.headline: A College in Maine That Tackles Climate Change, One Class at a Time
articles.snippet: As institutions look for ways to fight climate change, the College of the Atlantic has made the search for solutions a central part of its curriculum.
articles.abstract: As institutions look for ways to fight climate change, the College of the Atlantic has made the search for solutions a central part of its curriculum.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAR HARBOR, Me. — Like many residents of this picturesque island town on the edge of Acadia National Park, Zach Soares had trouble keeping his house warm, going through five cords of wood in the winter. So he jumped at an offer last year for free energy improvements through a class project at the College of the Atlantic, where he works.

articles.headline: Obama Overtime Rule Scratches the Surface in Helping the Middle Class
articles.snippet: Though labor welcomed President Obama’s action, observers said wage stagnation is the bigger problem.
articles.abstract: Though labor welcomed President Obama’s action, observers said wage stagnation is the bigger problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the ambition of President Obama’s plan to significantly expand the number of Americans eligible for overtime pay, the proposal falls well short of helping substantially increase middle-class wages, its chief advertised benefit.

articles.headline: The Bonds That Broke Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: A confluence of factors built up the island’s debt: tax exemption, the use of bonds to plug budget holes, and supposed ironclad guarantees.
articles.abstract: A confluence of factors built up the island’s debt: tax exemption, the use of bonds to plug budget holes, and supposed ironclad guarantees.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Puerto Rico’s governor told lawmakers and citizens on Monday that the commonwealth could not pay its $72 billion in debt, many wondered how a small, seemingly low-key American island in the Caribbean could have amassed a debt big enough to crush it.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Fight to Save Puerto Rico Investments
articles.snippet: Hedge funds see the governor’s call for debt restructuring as more of an opening salvo in a negotiation than an indication of imminent defaults.
articles.abstract: Hedge funds see the governor’s call for debt restructuring as more of an opening salvo in a negotiation than an indication of imminent defaults.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hedge funds like Appaloosa Management, Paulson & Company and Blue Mountain Capital gathered in a conference room at the Barclays offices in Midtown Manhattan last September to talk about what was then the hottest trade: Puerto Rico.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: U.S. Chamber Fights Smoking Laws While Hospitals and Insurers Sit on Its Board
articles.snippet: Four executives of leading health care organizations are members of the board of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which is engaged in a worldwide campaign to thwart antismoking laws.
articles.abstract: Four executives of leading health care organizations are members of the board of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which is engaged in a worldwide campaign to thwart antismoking laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, wants its members to stop smoking.

articles.headline: Jihadist Attacks on Egypt Grow Fiercer
articles.snippet: Two years after President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi led a military takeover promising to restore order and security in Egypt, he faces a rising jihadist insurgency.
articles.abstract: Two years after President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi led a military takeover promising to restore order and security in Egypt, he faces a rising jihadist insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Two years after President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi led a military takeover promising to restore order and security in Egypt, he faces a rising jihadist insurgency that has shaken the stability of this most populous Arab state, a key ally of the United States.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick
